arXiv:2307.01043v3 [astro-ph.CO] 15 Feb 2024

Component-separated, CIB-cleaned thermal Sunyaev–Zel’dovich maps from Planck PR4 data with a flexible public needlet ILC pipeline

Fiona McCarthy fmccarthy@flatironinstitute.org Center for Computational Astrophysics, Flatiron Institute, New York, NY, USA 10010    J. Colin Hill jch2200@columbia.edu Department of Physics, Columbia University, 538 West 120th Street, New York, NY, USA 10027 Center for Computational Astrophysics, Flatiron Institute, New York, NY, USA 10010
(February 15, 2024)
Abstract

We use the full-mission Planck PR4 data to construct maps of the thermal Sunyaev–Zel’dovich effect (Compton-y𝑦yitalic_y parameter) in our Universe. To do so, we implement a custom needlet internal linear combination (NILC) pipeline in a Python package, pyilc, which we make publicly available. We publicly release our Compton-y𝑦yitalic_y maps, which we construct using various constrained ILC (“deprojection”) options in order to minimize contamination from the cosmic infrared background (CIB) in the reconstructed signal. In particular, we use a moment-based deprojection which minimizes sensitivity to the assumed frequency dependence of the CIB. Our code pyilc performs needlet or harmonic ILC on mm-wave sky maps in a flexible manner, with options to deproject various components on all or some scales. We validate our maps and compare them to the official Planck 2015 y𝑦yitalic_y-map, finding that we obtain consistent results on large scales and 10-20% lower noise on small scales. We expect that these maps will be useful for many auto- and cross-correlation analyses; in a companion paper, we use them to measure the tSZ – CMB lensing cross-correlation. We anticipate that pyilc will be useful both for data analysis and for pipeline validation on simulations to understand the propagation of foreground components through a full NILC pipeline.

I Introduction

Observations of the millimeter-wave sky contain contributions from many sources, both Galactic and extragalactic. The signals of cosmological interest include, of course, the primary cosmic microwave background (CMB) Dicke et al. (1965); Penzias and Wilson (1965) — the photons that have been free-streaming since recombination without scattering — along with the Sunyaev–Zel’dovich (SZ) effect Zeldovich and Sunyaev (1969); Sunyaev and Zeldovich (1970), which is sourced by the scattering of the CMB photons from free electrons in the late Universe, and the cosmic infrared background (CIB) Puget et al. (1996); Dwek et al. (1998); Fixsen et al. (1998), which is the thermal radiation of dust grains in star-forming galaxies that are heated by starlight. As we can extract very different information from the different signals, it is useful to be able to separate them. It is common to do so by observing the sky at multiple frequencies and separating the signals based on their differing frequency behavior. In particular, the CMB intensity behaves as a perfect blackbody, with a temperature of 2.726 KK\mathrm{K}roman_K Fixsen et al. (1996); Mather et al. (1999); Fixsen (2009). The thermal SZ (tSZ) effect — the scattering of CMB photons by high-temperature electrons — induces a well-understood distortion in this spectrum, allowing the tSZ anisotropies to be separated cleanly from the primary CMB.

Many component separation algorithms exist for performing such separation (see, e.g., Bennett et al. (2003); Martínez-González et al. (2003); Eriksen et al. (2008); Seljebotn et al. (2017); Delabrouille et al. (2009); Remazeilles et al. (2011a); Cardoso et al. (2008); Hurier et al. (2013)). In particular, we focus on the internal linear combination (ILC), a method that creates linear combinations of maps using the well-understood frequency behavior of a signal of interest, such as the blackbody CMB or the tSZ effect, and which has been applied to CMB data for decades Bennett et al. (2003). Importantly, this is a “blind” component separation technique, in that the frequency behavior of the contaminants does not need to be known a priori. This is necessary, as the CIB — while observed to generally behave as a modified blackbody, with its emission dominant (with respect to the CMB) at higher frequencies (≳greater-than-or-equivalent-to\gtrsim≳353 GHz, although on small scales the CIB anisotropies are dominant at lower frequencies than this) — does not have a well-understood spectral energy distribution (SED), or frequency dependence, that can be derived from first principles. However, when the SED of a contaminant is known, this information can be used in the ILC to create a map that is completely insensitive to this contaminant Chen and Wright (2009); Remazeilles et al. (2011b) (or partially less sensitive than the unconstrained estimate Abylkairov et al. (2021)), although at the expense of higher variance in the overall reconstruction. This “deprojection” of foreground components, known as a “constrained” ILC, is useful for example in the case of cross-correlations, when one is cross-correlating a component of interest with another signal that is highly correlated with a contaminant.

In this work, we use a needlet ILC (NILC) algorithm to construct maps of the tSZ effect using Planck PR4 (NPIPE) data Planck Collaboration et al. (2020a); we note that several y𝑦yitalic_y-maps have previously been made with Planck data Hill and Spergel (2014); Planck Collaboration et al. (2016a); Tanimura et al. (2022); Chandran et al. (2023). We also release maps in which we have deprojected the CIB in various ways, both with a standard CIB deprojection using an estimate of the CIB SED, and in a more theory-independent method where we deproject the first moments of the CIB SED, following the methods of Chluba et al. (2017); in a companion paper McCarthy and Hill (2024) we use these maps to measure the cross-correlation of the tSZ signal with CMB lensing convergence (κ𝜅\kappaitalic_κ) in Planck PR4 data using a publicly-available Planck κ𝜅\kappaitalic_κ reconstruction Carron et al. (2022).

We validate our Compton-y𝑦yitalic_y maps and compare them to that from the 2015 Planck release Planck Collaboration et al. (2016a). While this work was in the final stages of preparation, a similar analysis performing NILC on Planck PR4 data appeared Chandran et al. (2023). We defer a comparison to this map to future work.

A central purpose of this paper is also to release a user-friendly Python package pyilc, a flexible code which can perform needlet and harmonic ILC on curved-sky maps for various specifications of needlet domains. This is (to our knowledge) the first publicly available needlet ILC code.

This paper is structured as follows. In Section II we describe the datasets we use to construct the ILC maps. Section III presents a pedagogical overview of the NILC algorithm and the “ILC bias”. In Section IV we describe our pipeline to construct a y𝑦yitalic_y-map from the data using the NILC approach, including our exact analysis settings. Section V discusses the various CIB deprojection options that we implement. In Section VI we validate our y𝑦yitalic_y-maps, compute their power spectra, compare them to that of the official Planck release, and quantify the amount of CIB contamination in the various deprojections. We discuss our results and conclude in Section VII.

II Data

We use the single-frequency full-mission maps from the Planck NPIPE data release (PR4) Planck Collaboration et al. (2020a) in our analysis. These maps are provided in μ⁢K𝜇K\mathrm{\mu K}italic_μ roman_K (CMB thermodynamic temperature units) at all frequencies, so we do not need to convert between Jy/srJysr\mathrm{Jy/sr}roman_Jy / roman_sr and μ⁢K𝜇K\mathrm{\mu K}italic_μ roman_K (as might have been necessary for previous releases of the Planck single-frequency maps, some of which provided the highest-frequency maps in Jy/srJysr\mathrm{Jy/sr}roman_Jy / roman_sr). Note that the kinematic solar dipole, which is sourced by the Doppler boosting of the CMB monopole due to our proper motion with respect to the CMB rest frame (in particular our motion through the Galaxy), is not subtracted from these maps. As this is much brighter than the intrinsic CMB fluctuations (with an amplitude of ≈3367⁢μ⁢Kabsent3367𝜇K\approx 3367\,\mathrm{\mu K}≈ 3367 italic_μ roman_K Planck Collaboration et al. (2020a), cf. the characteristic CMB fluctuation amplitude of ∼40⁢μ⁢Ksimilar-toabsent40𝜇K\sim 40\,\mathrm{\mu K}∼ 40 italic_μ roman_K), we subtract it from the maps before using them. To ensure we subtract the same dipole from each map, we use the solar dipole estimation from the Commander component-separation analysis of the NPIPE maps111This is available on NERSC at $CFS/cmb/data/planck2020/all_data/commander_dipole_templates/planck/dipole_CMB_n4096_K.fits. We also subtract the mean of each map before further analysis.

We use the 30, 44, 70, 100, 143, 217, 353, 545, and 857 GHz single-frequency maps. The observed sky signal in these maps is convolved with the Planck instrument beam at the corresponding frequency. We approximate these beams as being Gaussian, with full width at half maximum values (FWHMs) given in Table 1 Planck Collaboration et al. (2020b). To characterize fully the frequency response of each map, we use the passbands given in Refs. Planck Collaboration et al. (2014a, b).

We also use the half-ring split maps from the NPIPE release. These maps are subset maps of the full-mission maps described above, each with the same passbands, beams, etc. as the full-mission maps described above, but with independent noise realizations; as such, each half-ring map is noisier than the full-mission map, but they are useful for power spectrum analysis as their cross-power spectrum does not contain bias due to correlations in the instrumental noise. With these maps, we build two independent split maps of the Compton-y𝑦yitalic_y signal.

We use a needlet ILC algorithm to construct a full-sky tSZ map from these frequency maps, with various choices for contaminant deprojection. We discuss the specific details of our needlet ILC pipeline in detail in Section IV.

III The needlet ILC algorithm

In this section, we discuss the ILC and NILC in general, beginning in Part III.1 with a general definition of ILC, and describing the NILC in Part III.2. We discuss the constrained ILC, which can be used to deproject specific foreground components with known frequency dependence, in Part III.3. Finally in Section III.4, we discuss the ILC bias. Note that in this section, we remain very general, specializing to the specific details of our NILC pipeline in Section IV.

Throughout, we use lower-case Latin indices i,j,k,l,m,n,…𝑖𝑗𝑘𝑙𝑚𝑛…i,j,k,l,m,n,...italic_i , italic_j , italic_k , italic_l , italic_m , italic_n , … to label components of vectors or matrices in frequency space; subscript ℓ,mℓ𝑚\ell,mroman_ℓ , italic_m indices refer to discrete harmonic-space multipole coefficients (while the symbol m𝑚mitalic_m may seem overloaded, it will always be clear from context to what we refer). Greek indices α,β,…𝛼𝛽…\alpha,\beta,...italic_α , italic_β , … refer to components in the space of sky components that we preserve or deproject.

III.1 ILC

The internal linear combination (ILC) (see, e.g., Bennett et al. (2003) for an early application reconstructing a CMB map using the WMAP data) relies on knowledge of the frequency dependence of a signal to isolate it by taking a linear combination of multi-frequency measurements. In particular, assuming the temperature anisotropy T𝑇Titalic_T in frequency channel i𝑖iitalic_i in direction n^^𝑛\hat{n}over^ start_ARG italic_n end_ARG is given by

Any linear combination of the temperature maps

is unbiased to the signal of interest, in that it can be written as

s~⁢(n^)=s⁢(n^)+n~⁢(n^)~𝑠^𝑛𝑠^𝑛~𝑛^𝑛\tilde{s}(\hat{n})=s(\hat{n})+\tilde{n}(\hat{n})over~ start_ARG italic_s end_ARG ( over^ start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ) = italic_s ( over^ start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ) + over~ start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ( over^ start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ) (4)

wi=aj⁢(𝒞−1)i⁢jak⁢(𝒞−1)k⁢l⁢al,subscript𝑤𝑖subscript𝑎𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝒞1𝑖𝑗subscript𝑎𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝒞1𝑘𝑙subscript𝑎𝑙w_{i}=\frac{a_{j}\left(\mathcal{C}^{-1}\right)_{ij}}{a_{k}\left(\mathcal{C}^{-% 1}\right)_{kl}a_{l}},italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG , (6)

where, here and to follow, the Einstein summation convention is assumed, i.e., repeated indices are summed over.

In the ILC approach, the frequency-frequency covariance matrix is estimated directly from the data, and so the only “external” knowledge that is needed is the knowledge of the signal’s frequency dependence aisubscript𝑎𝑖a_{i}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (hence the nomenclature “internal”). The covariance can be measured and the weights applied in various bases: for example, in real space, by measuring 𝒞i⁢jsubscript𝒞𝑖𝑗\mathcal{C}_{ij}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over the entire maps (or subregions of the maps) and calculating one weight for each frequency map; or in harmonic space, by calculating an ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ-dependent covariance matrix 𝒞ℓi⁢jsubscriptsuperscript𝒞𝑖𝑗ℓ\mathcal{C}^{ij}_{\ell}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and applying ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ-dependent weights to the harmonic coefficients of the frequency maps in separate multipole bins. The former is ideal if there is no scale dependence to the noise properties, e.g., if the noise and the signal all have power spectra with similar ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ-dependence. If the foregrounds have different ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ-dependence to the signal, or if different foregrounds are relevant at different scales in the different frequency channels, or if the instrumental noise becomes dominant at different values of ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ, then a harmonic ILC is more appropriate. We describe briefly each of these domains below.

III.1.1 Real-space ILC

If 𝒟realsuperscript𝒟real\mathcal{D}^{\mathrm{real}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_real end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT covers the entire sphere (or the entire area of the unmasked map), the ILC weights then only depend on the frequency channel i𝑖iitalic_i and are applied uniformly to the entire map. Alternatively, 𝒟realsuperscript𝒟real\mathcal{D}^{\mathrm{real}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_real end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can be a subset of the map, allowing for spatial dependence of the weights; this may be appropriate for statistically anisotropic fields, such as when dealing with the foreground emission from our own galaxy, which is highly statistically anisotropic. However, it should be noted that, while the true temperature is preserved within the domains, correlations on scales larger than each domain are lost in such an application.

Multipole-dependent weights are appropriate when there is different scale-dependent behavior of the foregrounds and instrumental noise, including foreground SEDs that depend on ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ, to allow for the variance to be adaptively minimized on all scales. However, the harmonic ILC, while optimal for a statistically isotropic field, is not equipped to deal with statistical anisotropy, such as that from Galactic foreground components.

III.2 Needlet ILC (NILC)

To combine the advantages of both the real-space and harmonic-space ILC approaches, the ILC domain can be defined on a needlet frame Delabrouille et al. (2009). Needlets Narcowich et al. (2006) are a construction of a spherical wavelet frame (a frame is similar to an over-complete basis) which allows for simultaneous localization in real and harmonic space. The frame is defined first by a set of harmonic-space window functions (indexed by capital Latin letters I,J,…𝐼𝐽…I,J,\ldotsitalic_I , italic_J , …) hℓIsuperscriptsubscriptℎℓ𝐼h_{\ell}^{I}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT which obey

∑I(hℓI)2=1subscript𝐼superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptℎℓ𝐼21\sum_{I}\left(h_{\ell}^{I}\right)^{2}=1∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 (18)

at each ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ. Each I𝐼Iitalic_I specifies a different “needlet scale”. The needlets are further defined by real-space domains 𝒟n^real,Isubscriptsuperscript𝒟real𝐼^𝑛\mathcal{D}^{\mathrm{real},I}_{\hat{n}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_real , italic_I end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_n end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT associated with each needlet scale, where 𝒟n^real,Isubscriptsuperscript𝒟real𝐼^𝑛\mathcal{D}^{\mathrm{real},I}_{\hat{n}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_real , italic_I end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_n end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be defined independently at each pixel n^^𝑛\hat{n}over^ start_ARG italic_n end_ARG (and 𝒟n^real,Isubscriptsuperscript𝒟real𝐼^𝑛\mathcal{D}^{\mathrm{real},I}_{\hat{n}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_real , italic_I end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_n end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are not disjoint over the pixels).

In practice, the needlet ILC consists of the following steps:

(19)

    The maps TiI⁢(n^)superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑖𝐼^𝑛T_{i}^{I}(\hat{n})italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ) are referred to as the “needlet coefficients”.   4. 4.

    The spherical harmonic coefficients of each ILC estimate are then computed and filtered (again) by the needlet window functions, then transformed back to pixel space:

    zI⁢(n^)=∑ℓ⁢mhℓI⁢TILC,ℓ⁢mI⁢Yℓ⁢m⁢(n^).superscript𝑧𝐼^𝑛subscriptℓ𝑚superscriptsubscriptℎℓ𝐼superscriptsubscript𝑇ILCℓ𝑚𝐼subscript𝑌ℓ𝑚^𝑛z^{I}(\hat{n})=\sum_{\ell m}h_{\ell}^{I}{T_{\mathrm{ILC},\ell m}^{I}}Y_{\ell m% }(\hat{n})\,.italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ILC , roman_ℓ italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ) . (23)

    These final maps are then added to arrive at the final NILC estimate:

    TNILC⁢(n^)=∑IzI⁢(n^).superscript𝑇NILC^𝑛subscript𝐼superscript𝑧𝐼^𝑛T^{\mathrm{NILC}}(\hat{n})=\sum_{I}z^{I}(\hat{n})\,.italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_NILC end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ) . (24)

    Note that the condition in Eq. (18) guarantees that signal power is preserved in this series of operations.

III.3 Deprojection of foregrounds: constrained ILC

The weights in Eq. (5) are chosen to minimize the variance in the recovered map. However, sometimes certain foregrounds can significantly bias a signal of interest and a slight increase in variance is an acceptable price to pay for a significant reduction of this bias. This can be particularly true for cross-correlation measurements using ILC Compton-y𝑦yitalic_y maps, as some foregrounds are more highly correlated with the field with which we are cross-correlating than the signal we are trying to isolate. For example, the CIB is a foreground for the tSZ effect, and is more highly correlated with CMB lensing than the tSZ signal is Remazeilles et al. (2011b). In such cases, one may choose to build a “constrained” ILC map, as described in the following.

If the SED of a foreground signal is known, we can “deproject” it from our final map. In particular, let us now say that the signal in the sky is

Ti⁢(n^)=ai⁢s⁢(n^)+bi⁢f⁢(n^)+ni′⁢(n^),subscript𝑇𝑖^𝑛subscript𝑎𝑖𝑠^𝑛subscript𝑏𝑖𝑓^𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑛′𝑖^𝑛T_{i}(\hat{n})=a_{i}s(\hat{n})+b_{i}f(\hat{n})+n^{\prime}_{i}(\hat{n}),italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ) = italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ( over^ start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ) + italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( over^ start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ) + italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ) , (25)

where f⁢(n^)𝑓^𝑛f(\hat{n})italic_f ( over^ start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ) is the foreground we wish to remove and bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i}italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is its SED. If the weights in the linear combination obey the condition

III.4 The ILC bias

The ILC bias is a well-known issue in the ILC algorithm Delabrouille et al. (2009), which is caused by the fact that the covariance matrix is estimated directly from the maps, using only a finite number of modes. Chance fluctuations lead to incorrect estimates of the covariance and can lead to correlations between the weights and the signal of interest. This can be minimized by measuring the covariance over a large enough domain with enough modes that the covariance matrix estimation is immune to chance fluctuations.

We can define the ILC bias as follows. Recall the signal estimate is

s~=∑iwi⁢Ti=s+n~~𝑠subscript𝑖subscript𝑤𝑖subscript𝑇𝑖𝑠~𝑛\tilde{s}=\sum_{i}w_{i}T_{i}=s+\tilde{n}over~ start_ARG italic_s end_ARG = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s + over~ start_ARG italic_n end_ARG (31)

where n~~𝑛\tilde{n}over~ start_ARG italic_n end_ARG is given by

n~=∑iwi⁢ni.~𝑛subscript𝑖subscript𝑤𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖\tilde{n}=\sum_{i}w_{i}n_{i}.over~ start_ARG italic_n end_ARG = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (32)

Note that this expression is only valid for real-space domains defined by top-hat window functions in pixel space; it is also possible to allow for more complicated real-space domains, such as domains defined by a real-space Gaussian window function, in which case Npixsubscript𝑁pixN_{\mathrm{pix}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_pix end_POSTSUBSCRIPT does not just count pixels but is weighted by the window function defining 𝒟n^real,Isubscriptsuperscript𝒟real𝐼^𝑛\mathcal{D}^{\mathrm{real},I}_{\hat{n}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_real , italic_I end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_n end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

IV Estimating the tSZ signal

The tSZ spectral distortion is given by

Δ⁢TtSZ⁢(n^,ν)TCMB=gν⁢y⁢(n^),Δsuperscript𝑇tSZ^𝑛𝜈subscript𝑇CMBsubscript𝑔𝜈𝑦^𝑛\frac{\Delta T^{\mathrm{tSZ}}(\hat{n},\nu)}{T_{\mathrm{CMB}}}=g_{\nu}y(\hat{n}),divide start_ARG roman_Δ italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_tSZ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_n end_ARG , italic_ν ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_CMB end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG = italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ν end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y ( over^ start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ) , (36)

where gνsubscript𝑔𝜈g_{\nu}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ν end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the tSZ spectral function Sunyaev and Zeldovich (1970):

gν=x⁢coth⁡(x2)−4subscript𝑔𝜈𝑥hyperbolic-cotangent𝑥24g_{\nu}=x\coth\left(\frac{x}{2}\right)-4\,italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ν end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x roman_coth ( divide start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) - 4 (37)

with x≡h⁢νkB⁢TC⁢M⁢B𝑥ℎ𝜈subscript𝑘𝐵subscript𝑇𝐶𝑀𝐵x\equiv\frac{h\nu}{k_{B}T_{CMB}}italic_x ≡ divide start_ARG italic_h italic_ν end_ARG start_ARG italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C italic_M italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG. Here hℎhitalic_h is Planck’s constant, kBsubscript𝑘𝐵k_{B}italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is Boltzmann’s constant, TCMB=2.726subscript𝑇CMB2.726T_{\mathrm{CMB}}=2.726italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_CMB end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 2.726 K is the mean temperature of the CMB Fixsen et al. (1996); Mather et al. (1999); Fixsen (2009), and y⁢(n^)𝑦^𝑛y(\hat{n})italic_y ( over^ start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ) is the dimensionless (and frequency-independent) Compton y𝑦yitalic_y-parameter that quantifies the integral of the electron pressure along the line of sight (LOS). An ILC map that preserves the SED given by Eq. (37) is a map of the Compton-y𝑦yitalic_y anisotropies in our Universe.

We construct a set of Compton-y𝑦yitalic_y maps from the single-frequency maps of the Planck NPIPE data release (PR4) Planck Collaboration et al. (2020a). In our “standard frequency coverage” (default) case, we use the maps at frequencies {30,44,70,100,143,217,353,545}304470100143217353545\{30,44,70,100,143,217,353,545\}{ 30 , 44 , 70 , 100 , 143 , 217 , 353 , 545 } GHz, i.e., we use all of the maps from the Low Frequency Instrument (LFI) and all of the maps from the High Frequency Instrument (HFI) except for that at 857 GHz. We also make an extended-frequency-coverage version which includes 857 GHz, and additionally a version which excludes both 545 and 857 GHz.

The NILC method has been previously applied to Planck data to construct y𝑦yitalic_y-maps, e.g., in the official Planck analysis of the PR1 (2013) Planck Collaboration et al. (2014c) and PR2 (2015) data releases Planck Collaboration et al. (2016a), along with other component separation algorithms, in particular the modified internal linear combination (MILCA) Planck Collaboration et al. (2016a); Tanimura et al. (2022). Ref. Hill and Spergel (2014) (hereafter HS14) used a harmonic ILC (HILC) to construct a Compton-y𝑦yitalic_y map with which to measure the tSZ-CMB lensing cross-correlation, Cℓy⁢κsuperscriptsubscript𝐶ℓ𝑦𝜅C_{\ell}^{y\kappa}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y italic_κ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Notably, Ref. Tanimura et al. (2022) applied MILCA to the NPIPE single-frequency maps to build a lower-noise y𝑦yitalic_y-map than the 2015 Planck map, and similarly Ref. Chandran et al. (2023) has recently applied NILC to the NPIPE maps.

In this section we describe our analysis settings for the NILC algorithm. In Section IV.1 we present the harmonic- and real-space filters we use for our NILC. We present the pre-processing steps that we apply before performing the NILC analysis in Section IV.2. We discuss our foreground deprojection methods subsequently in Section V.

IV.1 Harmonic- and real-space filter choices for the NILC analysis

The Gaussian filters GℓIsubscriptsuperscript𝐺𝐼ℓG^{I}_{\ell}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the needlet filters hℓIsubscriptsuperscriptℎ𝐼ℓh^{I}_{\ell}italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are shown in Figure 1.

Before performing the needlet decomposition of the single-frequency maps, we convolve them to a common beam. However, note that, while we perform the NILC with many input frequency maps, the lowest-frequency maps have much larger beam FWHMs than the highest-frequency maps, and the signal is exponentially sub-dominant to the instrumental noise on small-to-intermediate scales (after beam deconvolution). Thus, in practice, we drop particular frequency maps from the NILC on the needlet scales where we expect no information from these maps. In particular, we define a “beam threshold criterion” bthreshsubscript𝑏threshb_{\rm thresh}italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_thresh end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which we take to be bthresh=10−3subscript𝑏threshsuperscript103b_{\rm thresh}=10^{-3}italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_thresh end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. If, for a given needlet scale, the beam of a given frequency channel reaches this threshold at a lower ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ than the needlet filter does for that scale, we drop that frequency channel from the NILC. Mathematically: we find the multipole ℓhsubscriptℓℎ\ell_{h}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where hℓhI=bthreshsubscriptsuperscriptℎ𝐼subscriptℓℎsubscript𝑏threshh^{I}_{\ell_{h}}=b_{\rm thresh}italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_thresh end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (on the decreasing side of the needlet filter) and the multipole ℓbsubscriptℓ𝑏\ell_{b}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where bℓbi=bthreshsubscriptsuperscript𝑏𝑖subscriptℓ𝑏subscript𝑏threshb^{i}_{\ell_{b}}=b_{\rm thresh}italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_thresh end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We then require that ℓh<ℓbsubscriptℓℎsubscriptℓ𝑏\ell_{h}<\ell_{b}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in order for a frequency map to be included in the NILC at this needlet scale. If this criterion is not satisfied for the beam of a given frequency channel, then that channel is dropped from the NILC at this needlet scale. Note that this procedure assumes monotonicity of the beam function, and also assumes that the filter function has a peak (and thus a decreasing region). The latter assumption does not hold for the smallest-scale needlet filter (see Figure 1), so for this scale we simply use the same maps as used at the penultimate needlet scale.

The resulting real-space FWHM values that we use to construct our NILC maps are listed in Table 3; note that they in principle depend on the number of foregrounds deprojected Ndeprojsubscript𝑁deprojN_{\mathrm{deproj}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_deproj end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, with smaller real-space FWHMs allowed when deprojecting more components (at fixed btolsuperscript𝑏tolb^{\rm tol}italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_tol end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT). However, in practice, we compute the covariance matrices only once, using the filters of the Ndeproj=0subscript𝑁deproj0N_{\mathrm{deproj}}=0italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_deproj end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 case, as the covariance matrix calculation and inversion is the most computationally intensive part of the NILC. We then save the covariance matrices and inverse covariance matrices for use in the remaining NILC calculations, for different deprojection choices. As the real-space domains used in the Ndeproj=0subscript𝑁deproj0N_{\mathrm{deproj}}=0italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_deproj end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 case are larger than those required to satisfy the ILC bias threshold for Ndeproj>0subscript𝑁deproj0N_{\mathrm{deproj}}>0italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_deproj end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0, the ILC bias threshold will be satisfied in all cases. Note that, in practice, Nfreqsubscript𝑁freqN_{\mathrm{freq}}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_freq end_POSTSUBSCRIPT depends on the needlet scale, as we drop the lower-resolution maps from the higher-resolution needlet scales according to Table 2.

Once we have defined the domains 𝒟n^real,Isuperscriptsubscript𝒟^𝑛real𝐼\mathcal{D}_{\hat{n}}^{\mathrm{real},I}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_n end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_real , italic_I end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we calculate the mean and the frequency-frequency covariance of the needlet coefficients TiI⁢(n^)superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑖𝐼^𝑛T_{i}^{I}(\hat{n})italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ) on them by smoothing each quantity with a Gaussian beam of the appropriate FWHM. In particular, the mean is simply given by the smoothed needlet coefficient maps, while the covariance is calculated by subtracting these means from the full needlet coefficient maps and multiplying them together, then smoothing the result.

IV.2 Pre-processing details

Before applying the NILC algorithm to the data, we apply a mask to each single-frequency map to remove very bright Galactic emission and point sources. This prevents the dominant emission from these regions (which, even if retained, would be masked in the final analysis) from significantly affecting the ILC weights calculated slightly away from (but in the vicinity of) these regions, and thus allows for better component separation away from these regions.

We inpaint the regions of each map covered by these masks using a diffusive inpainting scheme, which iteratively replaces masked pixels with ≥4absent4\geq 4≥ 4 unmasked neighbors by the mean of the surrounding unmasked pixels. The Galactic mask we use is the same as that used in the pre-processing of the Planck 2015 NILC tSZ map Planck Collaboration et al. (2016a), which we download from the Planck Legacy Archive (PLA)444This is available at http://pla.esac.esa.int/pla/aio/product-action?MAP.MAP_ID=COM_CompMap_Compton-SZMap-nilc-ymaps_2048_R2.00.fits (field =3absent3=3= 3).. The point source mask we use is the point source catalogue mask from Planck, which we also download from the PLA, using the low-frequency catalogue for the LFI maps and the high-frequency catalogue for the HFI maps555These are available at http://pla.esac.esa.int/pla/aio/product-action?MAP.MAP_ID=HFI_Mask_PointSrc_2048_R2.00.fits (HFI) and http://pla.esac.esa.int/pla/aio/product-action?MAP.MAP_ID=LFI_Mask_PointSrc_2048_R2.00.fits (LFI).. These preprocessing masks are shown in Figure 2. The Galactic mask covers 2.85% of the sky; the HFI point source mask covers 1.37% of the sky; and the LFI point source mask covers 5.41% of the sky. The combination of the Galactic mask and the HFI point source mask covers 3.93% of the sky and the combination of the Galactic mask and the LFI point source mask covers 7.94% of the sky; the combination of all three covers 8.50% of the sky, which at the end defines the total masked sky area of our final NILC maps.

As the NPIPE single-frequency maps retain the dominant contribution from the kinematic dipole, before inpainting we remove the kinematic dipole as measured by the Commander component separation algorithm Planck Collaboration et al. (2020a), and then subtract the remaining monopoles of the maps. Finally, following Ref. Planck Collaboration et al. (2016a), we deconvolve the beams of each map (the beams of the Planck maps are listed in Ref. Planck Collaboration et al. (2020b); we repeat them in Table 1) and reconvolve all maps to a common beam of 10′superscript10′10^{\prime}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Note that, as the covariances are calculated in real space, the beam at which the NILC is performed can significantly affect the final result, as the needlet filters are so broad in scale that the large variance of the small-scale modes can contribute significantly if they are not sufficiently beam-convolved. Thus the weights can spuriously adapt to mitigate the variance sourced by the smallest-scale modes in these frequency channels. Such an impact could be mitigated by choosing needlet scales with less broad coverage in ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ-space. In this work, however, we choose to follow the official Planck analysis and perform the NILC on maps at 10′superscript10′10^{\prime}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT resolution.

V Deprojection of various components

In Section III.3, we discussed constrained ILC and foreground deprojection. In this section we present our specific choices for foreground deprojection, in particular for removing the CMB and the CIB.

V.1 Deprojection of the CIB

For many cross-correlation analyses of the tSZ signal with large-scale structure (LSS) tracers, it is necessary to deproject the CIB, which is also correlated with LSS and which can bias a ⟨y×L⁢S⁢S⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑦𝐿𝑆𝑆\langle y\times LSS\rangle⟨ italic_y × italic_L italic_S italic_S ⟩ measurement if unmitigated. However, unlike the tSZ and CMB signals, which display no frequency decorrelation and which have SEDs that are well understood from first principles and can thus be calculated theoretically, the CIB is not described perfectly by one SED. It is sourced by the line-of-sight integrated thermal emission of different objects; in particular, different frequency channels are sensitive to slightly different objects, as source emission at different redshifts will be redshifted into different frequency bands. This leads to frequency decorrelation between the CIB channels. However, as the correlation coefficients are ≳90greater-than-or-equivalent-toabsent90\gtrsim 90≳ 90% at the frequencies of interest Viero et al. (2013); Planck Collaboration et al. (2014d); Mak et al. (2017); Lenz et al. (2019), it is still possible to clean the CIB using multi-frequency measurements. Its SED does not need to be known for the unconstrained ILC; however, if we wish to explicitly deproject it, we must model its SED.

Let us explicitly write the CIB intensity as

To quantify the uncertainty, we perform Markov-chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) sampling of the posterior, using flat, linear priors on all parameters, resulting in a posterior region shown in Figure 3. We stress that these are not intended to be highly accurate posteriors for the CIB SED parameters, as we have not quantified appropriately the covariance of the data points. Instead, they are intended to give an idea of a realistic region of variation of the parameters. A note on the best-fit β𝛽\betaitalic_β, TCIBeffsuperscriptsubscript𝑇CIBeffT_{\mathrm{CIB}}^{\mathrm{eff}}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_CIB end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_eff end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and the halo model parameters

Often, the CIB emission is modelled with a halo model with certain parameters that can be fit to data. Many of these halo models model the SED of objects at a given redshift as a modified blackbody, and include in the model a functional form for the (possibly z𝑧zitalic_z-dependent) physical dust temperature TDsubscript𝑇𝐷T_{D}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and spectral index βDsubscript𝛽𝐷\beta_{D}italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (see, e.g., Shang et al. (2012); McCarthy and Madhavacheril (2021)). Often TD⁢(z)subscript𝑇𝐷𝑧T_{D}(z)italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_z ) is parameterized as follows:

TD⁢(z)=T0⁢(1+z)α,subscript𝑇𝐷𝑧subscript𝑇0superscript1𝑧𝛼T_{D}(z)=T_{0}(1+z)^{\alpha},italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_z ) = italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 + italic_z ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (51)

with T0subscript𝑇0T_{0}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and α𝛼\alphaitalic_α free parameters that are fitted in the analysis. For example, the halo model analysis of Planck Collaboration et al. (2014d) found T0=24.4±1.9⁢Ksubscript𝑇0plus-or-minus24.41.9KT_{0}=24.4\pm 1.9\,\,\mathrm{K}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 24.4 ± 1.9 roman_K and α=0.36±0.05𝛼plus-or-minus0.360.05\alpha=0.36\pm 0.05italic_α = 0.36 ± 0.05, along with βD=1.75±0.06subscript𝛽𝐷plus-or-minus1.750.06\beta_{D}=1.75\pm 0.06italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1.75 ± 0.06.

If one wants to directly use these parameters to deproject the CIB sourced at a given redshift, it is important to account for the appropriate redshifting of the CIB temperature. For example, to deproject the CIB emission from z=1𝑧1z=1italic_z = 1, one can calculate the temperature of the modified blackbody at z=1𝑧1z=1italic_z = 1 as 31.31⁢K31.31K31.31\,\,\mathrm{K}31.31 roman_K, and then redshift it to today: T⁢(z)/(1+z)=15.66⁢K𝑇𝑧1𝑧15.66KT(z)/(1+z)=15.66\,\,\mathrm{K}italic_T ( italic_z ) / ( 1 + italic_z ) = 15.66 roman_K (βDsubscript𝛽𝐷\beta_{D}italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is unaffected by the redshifting operation and can be directly used in the CIB SED). For α=1𝛼1\alpha=1italic_α = 1 (as for the evolution of the CMB temperature), this would be equivalent to always using T0subscript𝑇0T_{0}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The CIB monopole is sourced at z≈2𝑧2z\approx 2italic_z ≈ 2, which would predict a redshifted temperature of ≈12.1⁢Kabsent12.1K\approx 12.1\,\,\mathrm{K}≈ 12.1 roman_K, not far from our best-fit effective temperatures.

V.2 Deprojection of the first moments of the CIB

There is significant uncertainty on the parameters (β𝛽\betaitalic_β, TCIBeffsuperscriptsubscript𝑇CIBeffT_{\mathrm{CIB}}^{\mathrm{eff}}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_CIB end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_eff end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) of the CIB SED; additionally, it is not a perfect approximation to the CIB emission to describe it as an exact modified blackbody described by a single set of these parameters. For cross-correlations of the tSZ effect with tracers that are more highly correlated with the CIB than with the tSZ field itself (e.g., the CMB lensing potential), imperfect removal of the CIB due to a deprojection with the “incorrect” SED can result in a CIB residual that is still a significant bias to the measurement. This systematic must therefore be considered and mitigated when measuring such a cross-correlation, such as in our companion paper McCarthy and Hill (2024) where we measure the tSZ – CMB lensing cross-correlation.

In Ref. Chluba et al. (2017), a moment-based approach for the description and removal of mm-wave foregrounds was introduced. In particular, their method was designed to mitigate effects due to SED uncertainty or variation of SED parameters due to either spatial averaging within an instrument’s beam or along the line-of-sight; the latter is particularly important for foregrounds such as the CIB, which is not emitted at only one redshift but in fact has a wide redshift kernel and is a superposition of imperfect modified blackbodies at various redshifts.

In this approach, the underlying (fundamental) SED is parametrized by some free parameters 𝐩𝐩\mathbf{p}bold_p, such as a modified blackbody parametrized by (β,T)𝛽𝑇(\beta,T)( italic_β , italic_T ). One then considers variations of these parameters within the instrument beam (and/or sky map pixel) or along the line-of-sight, both of which generically lead to deviations of the “measured” SED away from the fundamental SED form. The observed SED can be represented as a Taylor expansion (in the parameters 𝐩𝐩\mathbf{p}bold_p) around a point in parameter space 𝐩¯¯𝐩\bar{\mathbf{p}}over¯ start_ARG bold_p end_ARG, and more accurately modeled using this Taylor expansion. The zeroth-order moment of the observed SED is the average SED, which can be written as the fundamental SED evaluated at 𝐩¯¯𝐩\bar{\mathbf{p}}over¯ start_ARG bold_p end_ARG. If there were no variations in the SED parameters, then no further modeling would be needed. However, in general such variations lead to higher-order terms (moments) in the Taylor expansion. Then, the more appropriate SED to use for deprojection in a constrained ILC would be not only the SED evaluated at 𝐩¯¯𝐩\bar{\mathbf{p}}over¯ start_ARG bold_p end_ARG, but the entire Taylor expansion. In particular, the SED and its first (and higher-order) derivatives with respect to 𝐩𝐩{\mathbf{p}}bold_p (evaluated at 𝐩¯¯𝐩\bar{\mathbf{p}}over¯ start_ARG bold_p end_ARG) can be considered as independent components to be deprojected in a constrained ILC. Of course, given a finite number of frequency channels, we do not have the freedom to deproject an infinite number of components, but with the multi-frequency coverage of Planck it is possible to deproject several components.

We will use this approach to deproject the CIB in a robust manner from our y𝑦yitalic_y-map. In particular, we deproject the first moment of the CIB with respect to β𝛽\betaitalic_β, which in practice amounts to deprojecting an additional component with an SED given by ∂IνCIB∂βsuperscriptsubscript𝐼𝜈CIB𝛽\frac{\partial I_{\nu}^{\mathrm{CIB}}}{\partial\beta}divide start_ARG ∂ italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ν end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_CIB end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ∂ italic_β end_ARG, and also the first moment of the CIB with respect to TCIBeffsubscriptsuperscript𝑇effCIBT^{\mathrm{eff}}_{\mathrm{CIB}}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_eff end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_CIB end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which similarly amounts to deprojecting an additional component with an SED given by ∂IνCIB∂TCIBeffsuperscriptsubscript𝐼𝜈CIBsubscriptsuperscript𝑇effCIB\frac{\partial I_{\nu}^{\mathrm{CIB}}}{\partial T^{\mathrm{eff}}_{\mathrm{CIB}}}divide start_ARG ∂ italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ν end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_CIB end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ∂ italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_eff end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_CIB end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG.

These moments are given explicitly by

For concision, we sometimes refer to these moment components as δ⁢β𝛿𝛽\delta\betaitalic_δ italic_β and δ⁢TCIBeff𝛿superscriptsubscript𝑇CIBeff\delta T_{\mathrm{CIB}}^{\mathrm{eff}}italic_δ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_CIB end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_eff end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT respectively. Note that, unlike the SED of the CIB itself, the moment expansion of β𝛽\betaitalic_β depends explicitly on the chosen pivot frequency ν0subscript𝜈0\nu_{0}italic_ν start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as at this frequency the CIB SED does not depend on β𝛽\betaitalic_β and thus the derivative exactly vanishes888When we deproject components in a constrained NILC, the normalization of their SED does not matter (when we preserve a component in the NILC, its normalization is important in order to interpret correctly the units of the final map). In the case of the SED of the CIB, ν0subscript𝜈0\nu_{0}italic_ν start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT appears as a normalization and can be divided out. The same is not true for the first moment with respect to β𝛽\betaitalic_β, as ν0subscript𝜈0\nu_{0}italic_ν start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT does not appear multiplicatively.. In all cases, we use a pivot frequency of ν0=353subscript𝜈0353\nu_{0}=353italic_ν start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 353 GHz.

We refer the interested reader to Ref. McCarthy and Hill (2024) for details of how this moment deprojection technique stabilizes the measurement of Cℓy⁢κsuperscriptsubscript𝐶ℓ𝑦𝜅C_{\ell}^{y\kappa}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y italic_κ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT even for different choices of the CIB SED parameters (β,TCIBeff)𝛽superscriptsubscript𝑇CIBeff(\beta,T_{\mathrm{CIB}}^{\mathrm{eff}})( italic_β , italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_CIB end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_eff end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

V.3 Deprojection of the CMB

The CMB, whose SED is known (nearly) perfectly, can be deprojected in a constrained ILC tSZ map with no uncertainty or need to consider additional moments. This can be useful for large-scale cross-correlations of the tSZ signal with LSS, as the large-scale CMB contains contributions sourced by LSS arising from the integrated Sachs-Wolfe (ISW) effect Sachs and Wolfe (1967). This ISW-LSS correlation (e.g., Lewis et al. (2011); Creque-Sarbinowski et al. (2016); Hill (2018)) can bias such measurements, including the tSZ – CMB lensing cross-correlation. However, we do not have enough frequency channels to deproject more than three components at small scales (unless 857 GHz information is included); see Table 2. Thus we elect to only deproject the CMB from the first five needlet scales in some cases, denoted “CMB55{}^{5}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT”. As the ISW is a large-scale effect, this should mitigate essentially all of the LSS bias due to the ISW contribution.

The (normalized) SEDs of various components of interest are plotted in Figure 5.

VI Compton-y𝑦yitalic_y map validation and comparison to Planck map

In this section we present and validate our Compton-y𝑦yitalic_y maps, estimate their power spectra, and compare them to the official Planck 2015 tSZ NILC map. We explicitly compute the auto-power spectra and 1-D histograms of our maps and compare them to those of the official Planck analysis (on the same region of sky) in Section VI.2. In Section VI.3 we quantify the variance increase resulting from our various deprojections, by comparing the power spectra of our undeprojected and deprojected maps; we also illustrate the effects of varying the frequency coverage in the NILC. Finally, in Section VI.4, we compare the level of CIB contamination in our maps to that of the official Planck release, and also present the results of deprojecting the CIB. We perform all power spectrum calculations throughout with NaMaster Alonso et al. (2019).

Note that the 2015 Planck map was made with the CMB deprojected, and so all direct comparisons between our map and the Planck map are done with our CMB-deprojected map.

VI.1 Map images

We show our resulting tSZ maps in Figure 6, including various deprojection choices and also showing the official Planck 2015 NILC tSZ map Planck Collaboration et al. (2016a) for comparison. For the cases when just the CIB or the CIB+CMB are deprojected, there is no significant change to the maps by eye. However, when we deproject δ⁢β𝛿𝛽\delta\betaitalic_δ italic_β, the map becomes visibly noisier; we see that when we deproject both δ⁢β𝛿𝛽\delta\betaitalic_δ italic_β and the CMB the map is even noisier, indicating that there is significant CMB contamination in the CIB+δ⁢β𝛿𝛽\delta\betaitalic_δ italic_β-deprojected map. Finally, the maps with both moments of the CIB deprojected have significantly higher variance, and it becomes difficult to pick out structures such as the Coma cluster, which appears as a bright point in the northern hemisphere (right hand side of the maps) by eye. In the legend of Figure 6, and later, CMB55{}^{5}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT-deprojection refers to the deprojection of the CMB on only the first five needlet scales.

VI.2 Comparison with Planck map: histograms and power spectra

To compare directly with the Planck y𝑦yitalic_y-map, we consider histograms of the Compton-y𝑦yitalic_y values in the maps and also compute their auto-power spectra (for our various deprojection choices) on the area of sky defined by the Planck y𝑦yitalic_y-map analysis mask, which is provided with the Planck y𝑦yitalic_y-map999It can be found at http://pla.esac.esa.int/pla/aio/product-action?MAP.MAP_ID=COM_CompMap_Compton-SZMap-masks_2048_R2.01.fits, with field=1.. This mask, which is apodized, covers 50% of the sky. We multiply this mask by the point source mask, defined by the union of the Planck HFI and LFI point source masks as described in Ref. Planck Collaboration et al. (2016a). When we estimate the power spectra, we apodize the point source mask with an apodization scale of 30′superscript30′30^{\prime}30 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT before multiplying it with the Planck analysis mask (for the histograms, we use an unapodized point source mask). The resulting apodized mask allows for analysis with an effective fsky=0.45subscript𝑓sky0.45f_{\mathrm{sky}}=0.45italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_sky end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.45101010Note that, at some level, the point source mask is correlated with the tSZ field itself; however, any biases resulting from this correlation (e.g., Fabbian et al. (2021); Lembo et al. (2022); Surrao et al. (2023)) are expected to be negligible at Planck sensitivity..

VI.2.1 Histograms

We show the histograms of the Compton-y𝑦yitalic_y pixel values in Figure 7, for our maps with no deprojection (standard ILC, blue), fiducial CIB modified blackbody SED deprojected (orange), and additionally with the first moment of the CIB SED with respect to β𝛽\betaitalic_β deprojected (green) and with both moments deprojected (red); we include all versions both with and without the CMB deprojected, with the CMB-deprojected versions shown in solid lines compared to the dashed lines for the cases when we do not deproject the CMB (we only deproject the CMB on the first five needlet scales in the case where we deproject both moments of the CIB due to the insufficient frequency coverage on small scales to deproject more components). We also show the histogram for the official Planck 2015 tSZ map in black. The Compton-y𝑦yitalic_y signal is highly non-Gaussian and the strong positive tail is indicative of the presence of tSZ signal due to groups and clusters, which we see in all of the maps except for the case when we deproject both moments of the CIB; in this case, the large foreground contribution is larger than this signal. We note that there is more noise in the CIB-deprojected maps, and significantly more noise in the moments-deprojected maps, as indicated by the broadening of the histograms. This is an inevitable consequence of deprojecting more components in a constrained ILC.

We note that the histograms of our no-deprojection (standard ILC) and CMB-deprojected y𝑦yitalic_y-maps agree very well with that of the Planck map.

VI.2.2 Auto-power spectra

We measure the power spectra of our y𝑦yitalic_y-maps to further characterize their properties. We also construct NILC y𝑦yitalic_y-maps with, and measure the cross-power spectra of, two independent split maps which have independent noise (and therefore no noise bias in the power spectrum). We show the results in Figure 8. We also calculate the auto-power spectrum of the Planck y𝑦yitalic_y-map on the same sky area. In all cases, we calculate the power spectra using NaMaster to decouple the mask mode-coupling matrix.

In Figure 8, and in all subsequent plots with auto-power spectra, we include a theoretical calculation of the tSZ power spectrum, calculated using class_sz111111https://github.com/borisbolliet/class_sz Bolliet et al. (2018, 2020, 2023), which is an extension of the cosmological Boltzmann solver class121212https://lesgourg.github.io/class_public/class.html Blas et al. (2011). This signal is computed in the halo model using the pressure-mass relation of Ref. Battaglia et al. (2012a). We refer the reader to McCarthy and Hill (2024) for a detailed discussion of the modeling of this signal.

We do not calculate Eq. (54) directly, but instead use NaMaster, which computes the Gaussian covariance accounting properly for the decoupling of the mask. Note that this requires us to have an estimate of Cℓ+Nℓsubscript𝐶ℓsubscript𝑁ℓC_{\ell}+N_{\ell}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT at every ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ, which we achieve by unbinning our measured C^ℓsubscript^𝐶ℓ\hat{C}_{\ell}over^ start_ARG italic_C end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

The auto-power spectrum of our standard ILC y𝑦yitalic_y-map is slightly lower (≈10−20%absent10percent20\approx 10-20\%≈ 10 - 20 %) on small scales than that of the Planck 2015 y𝑦yitalic_y-map, presumably due to the lower instrumental noise in the PR4 NPIPE data compared to PR3. In addition, we also see a significant decrease in the cross-power spectrum of our split maps compared to that of the Planck 2015 y𝑦yitalic_y-map splits, except for on the largest scales. This is presumably due to the improved foreground cleaning in our map, resulting from the lower noise in the NPIPE maps.

We defer a full analysis of the tSZ auto-power spectrum from our maps to future work, as this will require careful understanding of the propagation of foreground contaminants, likely using simulations (as in Ref. Planck Collaboration et al. (2016a)).

VI.3 Effect of various deprojections and varying frequency coverage

In Figure 9, we show how various contaminant deprojection choices used in our NILC analyses affect the final auto-power spectrum of the y𝑦yitalic_y-map. In all cases, when we deproject the CIB and its first moments, we use the best-fit CIB SED parameters from Section V.1, β=1.77𝛽1.77\beta=1.77italic_β = 1.77 and TCIBeff=10.14⁢Ksuperscriptsubscript𝑇CIBeff10.14KT_{\mathrm{CIB}}^{\mathrm{eff}}=10.14\,\mathrm{K}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_CIB end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_eff end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 10.14 roman_K. We see that deprojecting the CIB incurs a small increase in noise power, but the CMB deprojection leaves the power essentially unaffected, as long as either no other components or the CIB alone is deprojected. This is because the CMB is already the dominant astrophysical contaminant in the standard ILC, so the weights are quite similar regardless of whether it is deprojected. However, deprojecting the moments of the CIB incurs much more serious noise penalties, particularly if multiple moments are deprojected. Note that, for the case when we deproject both moments of the CIB, there are not enough frequency channels to also deproject the CMB on small scales, and so we only deproject the CMB in the first five needlet scales; we refer to this in the legends of Figures 9, 10, and  11 as “CMB55{}^{5}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT”.

Our fiducial y𝑦yitalic_y-map includes information from all Planck frequency channels except for 857 GHz. For comparison, we also construct maps including 857 GHz in the NILC, as well as dropping 545 GHz. We note that the official Planck analysis (as well as the analysis of Ref. Chandran et al. (2023)) uses 857 GHz only at ℓ<300ℓ300\ell<300roman_ℓ < 300, due to its uncertain calibration. In principle, one could co-add the ℓ<300ℓ300\ell<300roman_ℓ < 300 modes of our with-857 GHz map with the ℓ>300ℓ300\ell>300roman_ℓ > 300 modes of our no-857 GHz map to obtain such a map.

The effects of including 857 GHz and dropping 545 GHz are shown in Figures 10 and 11, respectively. As expected, as there is more (less) data, including more (fewer) frequency channels results in lower (higher) power in the final y𝑦yitalic_y-map. However, we note that when more high-frequency channels are included, more information about the CIB SED is required in order to deproject it robustly, and it can be more difficult to robustly remove all CIB contamination; we discuss this issue in detail in our companion paper McCarthy and Hill (2024).

VI.4 CIB contamination

We attempt to quantify the amount of residual CIB in our Compton-y𝑦yitalic_y maps by directly cross-correlating them with maps of the CIB. CIB maps are difficult to construct due to the difficulty of separating CIB emission from Galactic dust emission, which is dominant on large scales and has a very similar frequency dependence to the CIB. We use the CIB maps of Ref. Lenz et al. (2019), which were constructed by using HI data HI4PI Collaboration et al. (2016) as a tracer of the Galactic dust in order to clean the dust emission from the highest-frequency (353, 545, 857 GHz) Planck channels. The resulting maps of the CIB emission at these frequencies are very clean of Galactic contamination.

For this investigation, we use only the 857 GHz CIB map, as the maps were constructed with the PR3 Planck data and thus do not have maps built from the same independent noise realizations as the NPIPE maps. Thus, we do not have two independent splits that are required to make a measurement without instrumental noise bias. However, as we do not use 857 GHz in our default NILC y𝑦yitalic_y-map construction, we can make a measurement with the 857 GHz map that is immune to noise bias. It would be interesting in the future to repeat or extend the work of Ref. Lenz et al. (2019) to the NPIPE data in order to measure cross-correlations with the lower frequencies that do not contain noise bias. An additional advantage of using the 857 GHz map for the tSZ-CIB cross-correlation is that this is the channel in which the intrinsic y𝑦yitalic_y signal is most suppressed compared to the CIB. For lower frequencies (particularly 353 GHz and below), we would have to consider the ⟨yCIB−map⁢yNILC−map⟩delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑦CIBmapsuperscript𝑦NILCmap\left<y^{\rm CIB-map}y^{\mathrm{NILC-map}}\right>⟨ italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_CIB - roman_map end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_NILC - roman_map end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⟩ contribution to the signal.

We show in Figure 12 the cross-power spectra measured with the 857 GHz CIB map and our standard-frequency-coverage NILC y𝑦yitalic_y-maps for several deprojection choices. We also include the measurement using the official Planck  map. We perform these measurements with the cleanest map provided by Ref. Lenz et al. (2019), which covers 8.71% of the sky. We multiply the apodized mask provided by Ref. Lenz et al. (2019) with the mask used previously throughout this work, i.e., the official Planck  NILC mask combined with the point source masks. The final sky covarage is 8.47% in our tSZ-CIB cross-correlation measurement.

In Figure 12, it is clear that the CIB contamination in our y𝑦yitalic_y-maps is lower than that of the official Planck  y𝑦yitalic_y-map. This is consistent with the results of Ref. Chandran et al. (2023). It is encouraging that the lower instrumental noise in the NPIPE maps has allowed for improved subtraction of the foregrounds in this case.

In Figure 12, we also include a theoretical prediction for the intrinsic cross-power spectrum between the tSZ and the CIB emission at 857 GHz Cℓy⁢857superscriptsubscript𝐶ℓ𝑦857C_{\ell}^{y{\rm 857}}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y 857 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We note that there is significant model uncertainty in this prediction. The methodology that we use follows the halo model formalism used to calculate the auto-power spectrum. While we defer to our companion paper McCarthy and Hill (2024) an in-depth presentation of the halo model details, we note that the model in Figure 12 (which was calculated with class_sz) uses the pressure profiles of Ref. Battaglia et al. (2010); Battaglia et al. (2012b) to predict the tSZ signal along with the halo model of Ref. Shang et al. (2012) with the parameter values of Ref. Planck Collaboration et al. (2014d) to predict the CIB signal (see Ref. McCarthy and Madhavacheril (2021) for a detailed description of this incarnation of the CIB halo model). As the focus of this paper is not the CIB-tSZ cross-correlation, we do not consider a wider range of models (although note that a prediction for this signal was made in Ref. Maniyar et al. (2021), and it would be interesting to use this data to constrain this model). We note that, if it is truly CIB-free, the fully moment-deprojected (CIB+δ⁢β𝛿𝛽\delta\betaitalic_δ italic_β+δ⁢TeffCIB𝛿superscriptsubscript𝑇effCIB\delta T_{\mathrm{eff}}^{\mathrm{CIB}}italic_δ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_eff end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_CIB end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT+CMB55{}^{5}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT) data points in Figure 12 can be interpreted directly as a measurement of the intrinsic cross-correlation of Compton-y𝑦yitalic_y and the CIB. Such a measurement was previously made with Planck  data in Ref. Planck Collaboration et al. (2016b). We defer to future work a comparison between our data and the measurements in this reference. Indeed, our work in Ref. McCarthy and Hill (2024) relies on the assumption that the fully moment-deprojected y𝑦yitalic_y-map is indeed negligibly contaminated by CIB. We note that the CIB+δ⁢β𝛿𝛽\delta\betaitalic_δ italic_β+δ⁢TeffCIB𝛿superscriptsubscript𝑇effCIB\delta T_{\mathrm{eff}}^{\mathrm{CIB}}italic_δ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_eff end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_CIB end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT+CMB55{}^{5}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT-deprojected points in Figure 12 are indeed stable to variations in the assumed CIB SED, as shown in Figure 13 (the same is not true of the CIB deprojection or the CIB+δ⁢β𝛿𝛽\delta\betaitalic_δ italic_β deprojection). In Figure 12, we also include the data points as measured by Ref. Planck Collaboration et al. (2016b) for Cℓy⁢857superscriptsubscript𝐶ℓ𝑦857C_{\ell}^{y857}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y 857 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which we have digitized from their Figure 15.131313Note that their points are given in units of the Compton-y𝑦yitalic_y parameter; we convert from Compton-y𝑦yitalic_y to Jy/sr using the conversion factors appropriate for 857 GHz in Table 6 of Ref. Planck Collaboration et al. (2014b). As such, we hope that these maps will make possible a fruitful joint CIB-tSZ analysis.

VII Discussion

In this work, we have presented pyilc, a fully public Python package to perform NILC on full-sky HEALPix maps. We hope that pyilc will be useful both for analyses of real data, to isolate maps of the CMB and tSZ signals and any other component whose spectral signature is known, as well as for analyses of simulations, in particular in cases where one wants to test a signal-extraction pipeline on realistic data and to understand biases due to foregrounds. We have validated that our implementation in pyilc produces maps that closely match the official Planck tSZ maps (when making the same analysis choices), which were produced with a non-public pipeline. Our code is fully available and easily extensible to consider other sky components and other deprojection options.

We have used pyilc to perform NILC on the Planck NPIPE data to isolate the (almost) full-sky Compton-y𝑦yitalic_y signal in our Universe. We note that y𝑦yitalic_y-maps have previously been made with this data Tanimura et al. (2022); Chandran et al. (2023), as well as in the official Planck analysis Planck Collaboration et al. (2014c, 2016a). We have made several improvements to the analysis, including a slightly different input-map-processing step where we mask the point sources such that they do not contribute to the calculation of the NILC weights; as point sources are always masked in any final analysis mask, this does not affect any science obtained from the maps, but improves their noise properties and usable sky fractions. Additionally, we provide y𝑦yitalic_y-maps where we have explicitly removed the CIB by deprojecting both a modified blackbody component and its first moments. Our CMB-deprojected tSZ map has ≈10absent10\approx 10≈ 10% lower noise than that in the official Planck  2015 tSZ map.

We quantify the amount of CIB contamination in our maps by directly cross-correlating them with maps of the CIB. We find that our maps have less CIB contamination than the 2015 Planck  NILC map. We have also presented CIB-moment-deprojected y𝑦yitalic_y-maps, which we hope can be used to measure ⟨y−L⁢S⁢S⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑦𝐿𝑆𝑆\left<y-LSS\right>⟨ italic_y - italic_L italic_S italic_S ⟩ cross-correlations without CIB bias.

We use these y𝑦yitalic_y-maps in our companion paper McCarthy and Hill (2024) to detect the cross-correlation of the reconstructed CMB lensing signal and the tSZ signal, for only the second time Hill and Spergel (2014), and with significantly more robustness against CIB contamination Hurier (2015). We hope that our techniques for removing the CIB from such a measurement will be useful for a wide range of future tSZ cross-correlation analyses, including the tSZ-CIB cross-correlation Maniyar et al. (2021); Planck Collaboration et al. (2016b).

We note that Planck y𝑦yitalic_y-maps, while currently state-of-the-art, will shortly be surpassed in signal-to-noise ratio by upcoming data from ACT Henderson et al. (2016), SPT-3G Benson et al. (2014), and soon the Simons Observatory Ade et al. (2019). However, the Planck data will remain dominant in the Compton-y𝑦yitalic_y reconstruction for the foreseeable future at ℓ≲1000less-than-or-similar-toℓ1000\ell\lesssim 1000roman_ℓ ≲ 1000, as atmospheric noise becomes too large at low multipoles for ground-based experiments to surpass Planck (in temperature) over this range — see, e.g., Figure 36 of Ref. Ade et al. (2019). A hybrid combination of the ground-based and space-based data will thus become the standard approach in the near future (as already demonstrated in Refs. Madhavacheril et al. (2020); Aghanim et al. (2019)).

VIII Summary of Public Products

We make various configurations of our Compton-y𝑦yitalic_y maps publicly available at https://users.flatironinstitute.org/~fmccarthy/ymaps_PR4_McCH23/. We also release our full NILC pipeline at https://github.com/jcolinhill/pyilc/, which takes as input a set of single-frequency maps and executes the NILC algorithms described in this paper; we include as explanatory files several input files we used to construct our NILC y𝑦yitalic_y-maps from the Planck data products. We note that the input is not the raw single-frequency NPIPE maps but instead the monopole- and dipole-subtracted, inpainted NPIPE maps described earlier in this work. We also release our inpainting code in the same GitHub repository as pyilc, along with our inpainting mask and several analysis masks, which are also at https://sdsc-users.flatironinstitute.org/~fmccarthy/ymaps_PR4_McCH23/.
